That’s done.Next, you figure out what you plan to *do* with this system, unless it’s just overcompensating for your personal shortcomings like the average Lamborghini owner.This is important, because the answer to this is going to impact everything from here on out.You also place help wanted ads in the usual places, because you’re going to need at least somewhere between 5 and 15 people to run the system, depending on what you plan to do with it. And you want to do this early as well, because interviewing and hiring experts is going to take a while - and you want those experts hired and on board for the next part….Now, you start thinking about logistics. Where will you put it, how do you get enough electric power for it, and what do you do for cooling? Knowing what you plan to do with it, you can make a first estimate of hardware, power, and cooling requirements. (This is one of the things you hired expert help for) You start this work first, because any construction has to finish before the system can arrive. We got lucky on the ones that I worked with, because we already had a quarter acre of raised floor server room. We *did* have to get the electric company to upgrade the local substation to handle several megawatts more, and run a new service feed about a mile from substation to our building. There was also additional construction work for cooling, and a bunch of other details like that.The next thing you do is you contact all the usual suspects: IBM, Cray, HPE, and a few others. You explain to them what you want to do with it, and they’ll help you pick out the number of cores you need, whether GPUs are a good idea, the interconnect between all the servers (and this actually matters more than the processors for some problems), a design for the system storage (you’re probably going to be buying petabytes of storage, and a bunch of servers just to manage it). You’ll probably need some high-end networking gear as well - and 100gigabit capable routers aren’t cheap.And here you end up doing a *lot* of trade-offs.. outfitting *all* the nodes with 3 terabytes of RAM gets expensive, so maybe you have 10 nodes that have 3 teras, and the others have only 512G of RAM. You have to figure out how many GPU-accelerated nodes you want. As you change these numbers, the numbers for your power feed, cooling, and networking change as well, and often not linearly, but a step function. You decide on a given network configuration that supports 20,000 nodes - but adding another 100 nodes requires a redesign of the network and another half-million dollars in gear.You argue with the vendor about acceptance criteria - what testing you plan to do to ensure the delivered system is usable for its intended purpose. They of course want the bar set as low as possible, and you want to insist on top performance before you pay for it.Oh - and those last 3 paragraphs? You’re doing all of that *multiple* times - once for each vendor still in the running for constructing this system. Expect anywhere from 9 to 18 months of this before you’ve settled on a vendor and a configuration. And you hit snags like “The vendor can’t actually make us a written proposal, because the server they want to use is a yet-unreleased product” (Yes, that actually happened to us, and required aOnce you get through all that, all that’s left is to sign some paperwork, and manage the install project, from completion of the power and cooling to arrival of multiple tractor trailers of cargo, to figuring out how to get the crane that will set the megawatt diesel backup generator under the elevated walkway over the pavement.Of course, there will be lots of snags along the way - everything from cables showing up with a different length than ordered, to Infiniband cards with firmware that doesn’t play nice with the release of OFED software you have, to…Finally, after 2 to 5 years of work, you’ll finally have the supercomputer. Now all that has to happen is setting up all the software, the job queuing subsystem, running all the acceptance testing, fixing all the things that fail during the testing, planning the Linpack testing for the Top 500 list…
